We respectfully disagree with the statement that "The authors suggest that the 31 increasing use of rapid, automated, syndromic molecular panels for respiratory viruses (RVs) 32 should be abandoned in favor of more limited PCR testing for RVs". As microbiologists and 33 clinicians, we rather suggest that we have the responsibility to promote diagnostic stewardship 34 in order to integrate these new technologies in clinical management, while considering their 35 strengths and limitations. However, it should be highlighted that there is not 41 enough evidence so far for a reduction in antibiotic prescription and duration or hospital 42 admission due to rapid molecular tests compared to conventional molecular ones [3]. The 43 ResPOC study concluded that a point-of-care (POC) assay was associated with a more 44 appropriate use of antiviral treatment, brief courses of antibiotics and shorter length of stay, 45 but no difference was observed regarding antibiotics' mean duration [4]. In addition, only 46 45% of patients in the control group were tested and the conclusions may have some 47 limitations.

FIGREF3.text: 50 clinical management when testing for influenza virus and RSV. Among paediatric patients, 51 the use of rapid tests demonstrated a decrease in emergency department length of stay, a 52 reduction of further diagnostic tests, and an increase in the appropriate use of antibiotics and 53 antivirals [5]. Similarly, a more appropriate use of oseltamivir, shorter time to isolation and a 54 reduction in length of stay were also shown among adults [6]. Nevertheless, considering the 55 methodological limitations, we believe that the conclusions driven by the post hoc analysis of 56 the ResPOC study regarding the impact of turnaround time on antibiotic use and length of 57 stay should be interpreted with caution [7]. The impact of short turnaround times on patient 58 clinical management has been well summarized in the commentary of Kuypers [8]. We have 59 already implemented a POC test for influenza virus and RSV at our institution. However, we 60 continue to perform conventional molecular testing for RV with in-house panels that 61 encompass diverse viral targets according to clinical presentation and epidemiology. 62 Regarding influenza virus infection specifically, we remind clinicians that antiviral treatment 63 should be started as soon as possible for patients with a suspected or documented influenza 64 infection and treatment and isolation measures should not be deferred while waiting for any 65 assay result [9]. 66 Clinicians should be also aware that clinical validation studies have assessed the performance 67 of some respiratory panels with suboptimal approaches and reported cumulative performance 68 results or positive and negative percent agreement as surrogates of sensitivity and specificity 69 [10]. Notably, certain panels encompass bacterial targets that have been validated with fewer 70 than 10 positive samples and performance has sometimes been reported to be lower than those 71 of viral targets [10]. Thus, clinicians should be particularly attentive when interpreting 72 cumulative performance results or percent agreement values, which may represent an 73 important and underappreciated limitation.74Overall, we consider that respiratory panels can be integrated in clinical management, but we 75 encourage the use of smaller, more targeted panels for pathogens that actually impact on 76 clinical management as part of a multiple-step approach of testing. Indeed, systematic first-77 line testing for a broad range of pathogens that are neither clinically nor epidemiologically 78 suspected and with no demonstrated impact on clinical endpoints and cost-effectiveness is 79 contrary to appropriate diagnostic stewardship and evidence-based decisions for diagnostic 80 and therapeutic strategies. Importantly, new technologies should serve the clinician's needs 81 and not be driven by marketing strategies. Furthermore, in the era of the SARS-CoV-2 82 epidemic, targeted testing is needed more than ever. Finally, we agree with Kuypers [8] that 83 the decision to implement a rapid molecular assay for respiratory pathogens requires 84 consideration of clinical and economic factors unique to each healthcare facility. Well-85 designed multicentre studies are needed using methods and standards to allow others to use 86 the results in evidence-based laboratory practice guidelines, as well as to increase evidence 87 regarding their impact in clinical management and cost-effectiveness.
